issue.title: Uploaded PNG images are not centered on crop
issue.body: ### Link to reproduction https://github.com/id3er0/payload-tests/tree/6ebefb69c0f43ecb35c25e7a63853ac774e7f301 ### Describe the Bug There is an issue with PNG files uploaded to a collection with `resizeOptions` or `imageSizes` settings: `fit: 'cover'` and `position: 'centre'` does not work for PNG but works for JPEG files. Demo for file converted from PNG: Demo for file converted from JPEG: ### To Reproduce 1. Run simple Payload project from https://github.com/id3er0/payload-tests/tree/6ebefb69c0f43ecb35c25e7a63853ac774e7f301. 2. Upload PNG image to `Images` collection. ### Payload Version 2.0.13 ### Adapters and Plugins _No response_

comment.body: @id3er0 Thank you for providing a reproduction! I'm looking into this now.

comment.body:
> I'm kinda mixed on whether we should _add_ a translation key as you have, or _remove/change_ the aria-label being using in that component.

I don't think we have a suitable translation key that already exists, and it does seem important to have an aria label here. I could change `menu` to `navigation` though? or something else?

issue.title: Live-preview package causes client side error in traverseFields
issue.body: ### Link to reproduction _No response_ ### Describe the Bug I am sure this is still wip but this is causing a client side error on my project which is blocking me rn. I first noticed this error after clearing my pnpm cache and reinstalling all modules. The error is thrown when I open my NextJS frontend (live-preview and draft preview is not affected). The error is thrown in the traverseFields file from the live-preview package `traverseFields.js:15 Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'forEach') at traverseFields (traverseFields.js:15:1) at mergeData (mergeData.js:17:1) at handleMessage (handleMessage.js:29:1) at onMessage (subscribe.js:17:1)` After some digging in the source code I have noticed that this happens because fieldSchema is undefined and forEach is called anyway. I was able to fix this locally by catching the undefined case `fieldSchema?.forEach(...)` in [line 24](https://github.com/payloadcms/payload/blob/main/packages/live-preview/src/traverseFields.ts) but I also thought that this code should not be called in the first place so there might be a bug in the conditions in the [handleMessage](https://github.com/payloadcms/payload/blob/main/packages/live-preview/src/handleMessage.ts) file which is calling the traverseFields eventually. This is only my assumption I hope it helps in fixing this issue. EDIT: I also found out that a similar problem occurs if you got for example the [MetaMask](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/metamask/nkbihfbeogaeaoehlefnkodbefgpgknn?hl=de) browser extension activated on Chromium. There is a runtime error happening in handleMessage file of the same package because it also makes use of a MessageEvent. The error occurs when trying to JSON.parse the data field of the MessageEvent. ### To Reproduce Really not sure how to reproduce this behaviour. Because it only happened after reinstalling my node_modules. I tried to use a fresh mongoDB table to make sure it wasn't my data causing this. I am using webpack, lexical, mongodb, NextJS custom server, drafts and live-preview. Sorry for the lack of information on the reproduction I hope pointing out the files from the source code helped. ### Payload Version 2.0.11 and 1.0.5 for live-preview-react ### Adapters and Plugins _No response_

comment.body: I'm getting the same. Strangely, if I click to open the live preview in a separate window, it works fine!

issue.title: Unaccurate error when trying to submit duplicate data into a field with 'unique: true'
issue.body:
### Link to reproduction

_No response_

### Describe the Bug

Using Payload 2.0 with Postgres. I have some fields (slugs to generate URLs) that I need to be unique across a collection, and while this works, the UX in the admin panel is lacking. 

In the console I get the error `ERROR (payload): error: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "slug_idx"`, but in the Admin UI all you get is a red error bar at the bottom that just says "Something went wrong", and the unique field that is the culprit is not highlighted. It is very confusing for a end user receiving this error, not knowing why their document failed to submit or what field to fix. 

"Sounds like a bug with the Postgres adapter" according to Elliot on Discord.

Slghtly unrelated, but an idea I had for slightly improved UX: designate unique field with an indicator similar to the red asterisk for required fields, so end users know that a field needs to be unique in relation to other documents in the collection while they are working on creating the data for the document. A little heads-up, maybe minimizing errors in the editing experience?

### To Reproduce

1. Create a Collection
2. Add a text field with `unique: true`
3. Create a Document in the Collection
4. Enter the value 'Test' in the text field with `unique: true`
5. Save the Document
6. Create a new Document
7. Enter the value 'Test' in the field with `unique: true` in the new Document
8. Save the new Document

### Payload Version

2.0.5

### Adapters and Plugins

db-postgres ^0.1.4, bundler-webpack "latest"

comment.body: Created a dicussion for it here: https://github.com/payloadcms/payload/discussions/3895 :)

issue.title: Warning Custom CSS file not found at undefined. Next.config.js
issue.body: ### Link to reproduction _No response_ ### Describe the Bug When building an app or even trying to start a development server, there is one annoying console.log that looks like that: It keeps informing me, that I need to specify custom CSS in next.config.js file, and is issued specifically by "withPayload". Funny part is that when I'm updating a 'cssPath' property in next.config.js file - it is treated as a string. Whatever I put in there - even functions - it is printed exactly the same in console. When I'm putting a path to CSS file - it is simply telling me that Custom css file not found at "my path to css file". When rolling back from payload 2.0. to 1.14 - it disappears. ### To Reproduce Simply run ```npm run dev``` in Next.js + PayloadCMS project. ### Payload Version 2.0.12 ### Adapters and Plugins bundler-webpack, db-mongodb, s3Adapter, cloudstorage, seo, redirects,

issue.title: Warning about React.createElement - invalid type
issue.body: ### Link to reproduction _No response_ ### Describe the Bug When trying to run: ```npm run generate:types``` or simply trying to build/dev - I'm getting this set of warnings in the console: I tried to roll back from Payload 2.0 to Payload 1.X and this does not show up in a console, so it's somehow connected with Payload. Seeing that it is even triggered while trying to generate types - it's looking like it is a problem specifically with Payload. I know it's not a breaking error, but still it is polluting console logs. ### To Reproduce Simply run one of commands for Payload - either build or generate:types. ### Payload Version 2.0.12 ### Adapters and Plugins bundler-webpack, db-mongodb, s3Adapter, cloudstorage, seo, redirects,

issue.title: Memory leaks that occurs on hot-reloads
issue.body:
### Link to reproduction

_No response_

### Describe the Bug

When working on a development in Next.js + PayloadCMS, after some hot-reloads I'm getting error about exceeding maximum allocated memory for Heap. It is currently set to 4GB. When monitoring a process using HTOP - you can clearly see that RAM usage is increasing until it crashes.

This bug started affecting my workflow right after upgrading PayloadCMS to the latest version(from 1.14 to 2.0)

### To Reproduce

Simply start the development server and make some changes in code and/or create a page in PayloadCMS and keep editing/saving this page.

### Payload Version

2.0.12

### Adapters and Plugins

bundler-webpack, db-mongodb, s3Adapter, cloudstorage, seo, redirects,

issue.title: fix: disable webpack hot reload on production
issue.body:
## Description

This fixes a regression. The issue is #3289 and it was fixed in #3319, but that was for Payload 1. Since Payload 2, the Webpack bundler is a separate package and apparently has the same issue. I've applied the same fix.

## Type of change

<!-- Please delete options that are not relevant. -->

- [ ] Chore (non-breaking change which does not add functionality)
- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)
- [ ] Change to the [templates](../templates/) directory (does not affect core functionality)
- [ ] Change to the [examples](../examples/) directory (does not affect core functionality)
- [ ] This change requires a documentation update

## Checklist:

- [ ] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works
- [ ] Existing test suite passes locally with my changes
- [ ] I have made corresponding changes to the documentation
- [x] I'm confident I don't have to do any of the above

comment.body:
@JarrodMFlesch this error popped up again in Payload 2.0.13. This time I'm pinging you that I've already fixed it and have made a PR. 😄

I can see you've already made this exact same fix for Payload 2 in #3320, but apparently the migration to the monorepo introduced the error back in b21b4719fc176dab689b7dd20e515dc4f6c40a20.

repo.name: payload
repo.description: The best way to build a modern backend + admin UI. No black magic, all TypeScript, and fully open-source, Payload is both an app framework and a headless CMS.
